text: Turned off comments a long time ago :upside_down_face:

elements.text: Turned off comments a long time ago

I agree with all of the above—you are not going to rank because search intent is split between reviews (3/10) and actual software home pages (6/10),. There are no guides there, indicating that when people search for ASsoftware, they already know what it is

Also, 30,000 words is practically a novella → this might work as a whitepaper or an ebook, but as a blog post it’s really hard to get through. And it would be whatever the topic is.

You could probably cut it into separate blog posts that target different kwds [example: the chapter called “How to choose an online appointment scheduling software” could be a standalone piece targeting a long-tail variation on the ‘choosing ASsoftware’ theme}

text:
If you've noticed this same post brings in some traffic, better to focus on optimizing it to bring in even more traffic for the keywords behind that traffic.

And since there are different chapters, each one should be written (or rewritten) to link back to your homepage for this particular keyword. 

It matches the search intent, so getting people to your homepage for this keyword could drive your end goal: conversion, as against a 30k guide.

text:
Hi all! I'm in the process of re-assessing our content distribution strategy. Our content is both educational and editorial, so each has its own goals and audiences. But would love to learn learn what's work for you to get the right content to the right people at the right time.

Would anyone be up for a chat this week? Thank you!

text: re-iterating a lot of the thoughts here. Unfortunately it looks like `Appointment Scheduling Software` is an intent that split between brands & comparison websites

elements.text: re-iterating a lot of the thoughts here. Unfortunately it looks like
Appointment Scheduling Software
is an intent that split between brands & comparison websites

text:
the way to approach ranking for this is to either create your own comparison article (eg. 20 best appointment scheduling softwares) and talk about your competitors.

OR to increase the brand presence of Genbook such that a search engine results page for `appointment scheduling software` is disappointing to a user when it doesn't have a "Genbook features page" result.

Which it doesn't quite look like you have a Genbook features page that describes why Genbook is a good `appointment scheduling software`:

`site:<http://genbook.com|genbook.com>` appointment scheduling software on Google returns your homepage:

text: Hello everyone :wave:, I am looking to learn more about client-side vs. server-side rendering and its impact on SEO. Anyone has experiences or resources to share? Thanks in advance :thankyou:

elements.text: Hello everyone
, I am looking to learn more about c
lient-side vs. server-side rendering and its impact on SEO. Anyone has experiences or resources to share? Thanks in advance

text:
<@U019MUQ6QKV> I wouldn't expect it to have any impact on SEO other than potentially page speed. The elements on the page in terms of the structure and the words are what impact SEO. Whether the page is rendered on a server or the client device doesn't impact a pages relevance to the query.

Now, "remain time" or whatever it was Rand called it (I forget) does matter and page load time _can_ impact that which can help your pages rank, or maintain their rank. Server-side would be your best bet on that front mostly because client-side is unpredictable and an end users device could slow down the render while the server is a known entity.

can

impact that which can help your pages rank, or maintain their rank. Server-side would be your best bet on that front mostly because client-side is unpredictable and an end users device could slow down the render while the server is a known entity.

text: If crawlers, like Google, can't render things they aren't going to index them, or potentially rank them lower because they can't see the content on the page.

elements.text: If crawlers, like Google, can't render things they aren't going to index them, or potentially rank them lower because they can't see the content on the page.

text: Hey Nate! I think we may have chatted about this a bit already, but for accessing new (to us) audiences we got some traction via high-distribution newsletters aimed at specific audiences we were targeting. Some of these were free (e.g. UX Collective just liked our content and thought it would be useful for their readers) and others paid (e.g. we sponsored a year of Product School's newsletter to all their students, which included a featured post each month). For reaching existing users, our own customer email is king. I really want to try in-product promotion, but that's been harder to get off the ground!

text:
Google is getting better about parsing JS however it’s delivered to the browser. If needed UX functionality affects crawability, in the meantime they're allowing dynamic rendering - where you essentially serve static bot-specific pages vs what user may see (to some extent, content shouldn’t vary drastically <https://developers.google.com/search/docs/guides/dynamic-rendering|https://developers.google.com/search/docs/guides/dynamic-rendering>). 

It’d be helpful to know your specific use-case, though. To clarify and make sure I get the context of your question. I’m assuming you’re running a Next.js site or similar and trying to optimize.

attachments.title: Dynamic Rendering | Google Search Central  |  Google Developers
attachments.text: Dynamic rendering can help crawlers process JavaScript. Discover how to implement dynamic rendering and learn the benefits for SEO.
attachments.fallback: Google Developers: Dynamic Rendering | Google Search Central  |  Google Developers

https://developers.google.com/search/docs/guides/dynamic-rendering

text:
Tbh it’s the product and its developer experience that either sells or dissuades devs.

Devs will checkout the CLI, APIs, SDKs of what they’ll be using. Maybe scope some documentation. And likely browse GitHub repos to see if there’s any OSS libraries/solutions for integrating said product in preferred/needed language and stack.

Developers often try before buy - so product-led (and technical content-led) is of utmost importance to them, else they’ll turn away/search/research alternatives if product doesn’t meet needs and product’s roadmap/changelog doesn’t show their needs being met anytime soon.
